column1: #Text=The Pennine Way is a designated UK National Trail in the United Kingdom running for 429 km ( 268 miles ) from Edale in Derbyshire to Kirk Yetholm in the Scottish Borders .
#Text=On its way , the route passes through parts of the Peak District , the Yorkshire Dales and Northumberland National Park .
#Text=The path was the idea of the journalist and rambler Tom Stephenson , inspired by similar trails in the United States of America , particularly the Appalachian Trail .
#Text=Stephenson proposed the concept in an article for the Daily Herald in 1935 , and later lobbied Parliament for the creation of an official trail .
#Text=The walk was originally planned to end at Wooler , but eventually it was decided that Kirk Yetholm would be the finishing point .
#Text=The final section of the path was declared open in a ceremony held on Malham Moor on 24 April 1965 .
#Text=Although not the longest of the UK 's long-distance paths , it is probably the best known and one of the more demanding routes .
#Text=It generally follows the higher parts of the Pennines , a chain of moors and hills running north â€“ south along the watershed of northern England .
#Text=The Pennine Way can be walked in either direction , but is more commonly followed from south to north .
#Text=This way you tend to have the wind at your back , and most travel guides ( including this one ) are written in this direction .
#Text=Although it is waymarked and requires no specialist mountaineering skills , walking the Pennine Way requires a good level of fitness , appropriate equipment and adequate navigation skills .
#Text=Accommodation is limited along some sections so if you are not camping , you might consider booking accommodation in advance .

#Text=In particular , the last day normally involves a high-level 25-mile walk across the Cheviots from Byrness to Kirk Yetholm , though off-route accommodation can be used to split the long walk in two .
#Text=The trail officially starts at The Nags Head pub in Edale .
#Text=Sheffield and Manchester are both around a 45-minute train journey away .
#Text=Bus services to Edale are very limited .
#Text=The route passes through or near the following ( landmarks in italic ) :
#Text=Malham village , Malham Cove and Malham Tarn
#Text=Tan Hill Inn ( highest public house in England )
#Text=Cross Fell ( highest point in the Pennines )
#Text=Many parts of the Pennine Way are remote , exposed and prone to sudden changes in the weather .
#Text=You should be familiar with moorland navigation and be suitably experienced and equipped for mountain walking .
#Text=The trail officially ends at The Border Inn in Kirk Yetholm .

#Text=From here , a bus service links to Jedburgh via Kelso where further connections can be taken to Newcastle upon Tyne ( total travel time approx. 2 hours ) and Edinburgh ( total travel time approx. 1 hour 45 minutes ) .
